text: Fast Neutrino Flavor Conversion at Late Time
Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Homi Bhabha Road, Mumbai 400005, India

We all know that in the dense anisotropic interior of the star, neutrino-neutrino forward-scattering
can lead to fast collective neutrino oscillations, which has striking consequences on ï¬‚avor depen-

dent neutrino emission and can be crucial for the evolution of a supernova and its neutrino signal.
The ï¬‚avor evolution of such dense neutrino system is governed by a large number of coupled
nonlinear partial diï¬€erential equations which are almost always very diï¬ƒcult to solve. Although
the triggering, initial linear growth and the condition for fast oscillations to occur are understood
by a well known trick known as â€œLinear stability analysisâ€ [1], this fails to answer an important
question â€“ what is the impact of fast ï¬‚avor conversion on observable neutrino ï¬‚uxes or the su-
pernova explosion mechanism? This is a signiï¬cantly harder problem that requires understanding
the nature of the ï¬nal state solution in the nonlinear regime. Moving towards this direction we
present one of the ï¬rst numerical as well as an analytical study of the coupled ï¬‚avor evolution of
a non-stationary and inhomogeneous dense neutrino system in the nonlinear regime considering
one spatial dimension and a spectrum of velocity modes. This work gives a clear picture of the
ï¬nal state ï¬‚avor dynamics of such systems specifying its dependence on space-time coordinates,
phase space variables as well as the lepton asymmetry and thus can have signiï¬cant implications
for the supernova astrophysics as well as its associated neutrino phenomenology even for the most
realistic scenario.
